title: What to expect in the September jobs report
text:
U.S. employers likely added workers at a slower rate in September, consensus economists believe, in another sign that a growth slowdown has overtaken the domestic economy.

The Department of Labor is set to release its report on the health of the U.S. labor market from September on Friday at 8:30 a.m. ET. Here are the main figures economists are expecting from the print, according to Bloomberg data:

Nonfarm payrolls: +145,000 vs. +130,000 in August

Unemployment rate: 3.7%, vs. 3.7% in August

Average hourly earnings MoM: +0.2% vs. +0.4% in August

Average hourly earnings YoY: +3.2% vs. +3.2% in August

The labor market has so far seen fewer new positions added over the course of the year while the unemployment rate held near multi-decade lows. The three-month average for new payroll additions through August was 156,000, versus 241,000 over the same three months of 2018.

Previously released employment data for September has provided mixed signals as to whether the relative resilience of the labor market will hold up heading into the final quarter of the year.

“For one, in the September survey week (the week that includes the 12th of the month), initial jobless claims continued to send no particular indication that firings have picked up and continues to show layoffs in the U.S. running at historically low levels,” Morgan Stanley economist Ellen Zentner wrote in a note Thursday. The four-week moving average for new unemployment claims was 208,000 during the week the Department of Labor conducts its September jobs report, versus a still-sanguine 212,500 now.

Teamwork, Group of workers on a road construction, team of people at work More

Plus, the Conference Board’s labor market differential – which represents the difference between the percentage of consumers who say jobs are plentiful and the percentage saying jobs are hard to find – remained relatively high at 33.2 in September, suggesting the labor market remained tight.

Disappointing data

But other data has been less upbeat around the employment situation. On Wednesday, ADP/Moody’s released a report showing private sector payrolls rose by 135,000 in September, missing Bloomberg’s consensus expectations by 5,000. August’s private payroll additions were downwardly revised by 38,000 to 157,000.

And after this week’s gloomy data on both the manufacturing and services sides of the economy, the last thing investors want to see is a disappointing Labor Department jobs report.

This week, stocks were whipsawed after the Institute of Supply Management released two separate reports showing that both manufacturing and service sector activity fell to multi-year lows in September.

Softness in U.S. manufacturing activity has been well-documented this year amid an ongoing trade war, and has been reflected in hiring trends in goods-producing industries. Consensus economists expect the Labor Department’s report will show just 3,000 manufacturing payrolls added in September, matching August’s print for the fewest additions since April.

Of more concern was the softness reflected in ISM’s report on the service sector, which comprises a greater portion of domestic activity and saw growth slow to the lowest level in three years. Within this survey, the employment index fell to a five-year low of 50.4, holding just above the neutral level of 50 to indicate just slight expansion in hiring.

“The message from the latest ISM surveys is unambiguous; firms are scaling back hiring plans quite aggressively,” Ian Shepherdson, chief economist of Pantheon Macroeconomics, wrote in a note Thursday. “Even if the other components of our composite hiring index are unchanged in September, the message from the ISMs is that job growth is heading south.”

Echoing the sentiments of many economists, Shepherdson pointed to fallout from the trade war as cause for the deterioration, with manufacturing already in contractionary territory and the services sector “extremely nervous over the impact of tariffs on consumer goods.”
description: U.S. employers likely added workers at a slower rate in September, consensus economists believe, in another sign that a growth slowdown spread across the domestic economy.
